MRN_Type_x: PMRN, MGH, BWH, FH, SRH, NSM, MEE, DFC
Report_Text: CT CHEST PULMONARY ANGIOGRAM (ACUTE)TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT pulmonary angiography was performed after administration of intravenous contrast using tailored dose modulation techniques. 3D angiographic postprocessing techniques were acquired in the form of axial maximum intensity projection images (MIPS).COMPARISON: CT CHEST (VASCULAR) WITH CONTRAST 2023-Jun-20FINDINGS:Pulmonary Angiogram:Technical quality: There is adequate opacification of the pulmonary arteries.Occlusive filling defect in the right lower lobe segmental pulmonary artery (4:432) andnonocclusive filling defect  in the right upper lobe segmental pulmonary artery (4:256) to suggest pulmonary embolism.Proximal to the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery, the main pulmonary artery is 3.8cm in diameter.Devices/Tubes/Lines: None.Lungs:No evidence of wedge-shaped opacities within the right upper and lower lobe distal to the filling defects in the segmental pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary infarcts.Emphysema in bilateral lungs with upper lobe predominant subpleural bullae.Dependent secretions in the trachea, with bronchial wall thickening and scattered mucus plugging in the lower lungs and dependent patchy opacities in the lower lobes and lingula.Pleura: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.Mediastinum: No thyroid nodules. Prominent right cardiac chambers. Mild amount of coronary calcifications.Lymph Nodes: No enlarged supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes.Upper Abdomen: Percutaneous gastrostomy tube terminates in the stomach. Probable left renal cysts, suboptimally evaluated due to streak artifact in the upper abdomen.Chest Wall: No chest wall mass.Bones: No suspicious lytic or blastic lesions. Degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.IMPRESSION:1.  Filling defects in the segmental pulmonary arterial branches of right upper lobe and lower lobe consistent with pulmonary embolism.2.  Prominent right cardiac chambers and main pulmonary artery can be seen with right heart strain.3.  Tracheal secretions with scattered mucous plugging and dependent patchy opacities in the lower lungs may represent aspiration.A clinically significant result was communicated and documented via a closed loop communication system.ATTESTATION: I, John Conklin, as teaching physician have reviewed the images, if any, for this patient's exam, and if necessary, have edited the report originally created by Lokeshwar Chinthakunta.Electronically Signed by: John M Conklin, MD on 7/27/2023  3:54 PM

Report_Text: SSX:Tachypnea,Tachycardia,Shortness of Breath,LUQ sharp pain,INDICATION: Tachypnea, tachycardia, shortness of breath, sharpleft upper quadrant pain.TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT scanning was performed through thechest following intravenous administration of 80cc Isovue 370.COMPARISON: Chest CT dated March 10, 2010.CT ANGIOGRAM: The study is technically adequate with a goodcontrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree.  Central arterialfilling defects are seen within multiple pulmonary vesselsbilaterally, with clot seen within segmental and subsegmentalvessels of right upper, middle, and lower lobes as well as theleft lower lobe and lingula.  The main pulmonary artery is notdilated, and there is no reversal of the RV/LV ratio to suggestright heart strain.CHEST: A small left effusion is noted with overlying airspaceopacities most likely reflecting atelectasis, though infarctcannot be excluded. The lungs are otherwise clear, with noconsolidation or pneumothorax.  There is no pericardial effusion.Dense atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta and arch vesselsare noted. There is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillarylymphadenopathy.  Mild multilevel degenerative changes are seenthroughout the thoracic spine. A 7 mm nodule is noted in theright upper lobe, unchanged from prior exam.LIMITED ABDOMEN:  Please refer to dedicated abdomen of same day.IMPRESSION:1. Multiple bilateral segmental and subsegmental pulmonaryemboli, without evidence of right heart strain.2. Small left effusion with overlying airspace opacities, likelyreflecting atelectasis, though infarct cannot be excluded.3. Stable 7 mm right upper lobe nodule.Critical results were communicated and documented using the AlertNotification of Critical Radiology Results (ANCR) system.I, the teaching physician, have reviewed the images and agreewith the report as written.This report was electronically signed by SCOTT WHITE MD(T)

Report_Text: CT CHEST PULMONARY ANGIOGRAM (ACUTE)TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT pulmonary angiography was performed after administration of intravenous contrast using tailored dose modulation techniques. 3D angiographic postprocessing techniques were acquired in the form of axial maximum intensity projection images (MIPS).COMPARISON: CT CHEST PULMONARY ANGIOGRAM (ACUTE) 2021-Oct-14; NM PET CT SCALP TO TOES 2021-Oct-21FINDINGS:Pulmonary Angiogram:Technical quality: There is adequate opacification of the pulmonary arteries.Breathing motion artifacts limiting evaluation of segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arterial branches in both lower lobes. However, there is a weblike filling defect in a right lower lobe segmental pulmonary arterial branch (5:469), which may be artifactual or represent residual thrombus seen on CT chest of 10/14/2021.No evidence of central, lobar segmental and bilateral upper lobe subsegmental pulmonary embolism.No evidence of right heart strain.Proximal to the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery, the main pulmonary artery is 3.0 cm in diameter.Devices/Tubes/Lines: None.Lungs: Interval increase in size of bilateral pulmonary nodules/masses. For example, dominant right upper lobe mass measuring 5.8 x 4.1 cm (5:149) previously 5.1 x 3.7 cm, 2.2 x 2.0 cm right interlobar nodule (7:39) previously 1.6 x 1.6 cm and 3.2 x 2.6 cm left lower lobe lesion (7:69) previously 2.5 x 2.0 cm. Interval increase in nodular consolidative opacity in the left upper lobe laterally (7:46). Bibasilar subsegmental atelectasis.Pleura: Decreased bilateral pleural effusions, now trace.Mediastinum: Heart size is normal. Small pericardial effusion, unchanged. Mild coronary artery calcifications. Large hiatal hernia with diffusely dilated fluid-filled esophagus.Lymph Nodes: Mildly enlarged right hilar lymph node measuring 1.2 cm (5:297)..Upper Abdomen: Please see concurrent abdominal CT  for abdominal findings.Chest Wall: Bilateral symmetric moderate gynecomastia..Bones: Multifocal predominantly lytic osseous metastases, for example involving T12 vertebral body posterior elements (10:103) and right lateral 7th rib (5:406). A new lytic osseous lesion in posterior right 3rd rib (7:20) with pathological fracture.IMPRESSION:1.  Weblike filling defect in a right lower lobe subsegmental pulmonary arterial branch, may be artifactual or represent residual thrombus seen on CT chest of 10/14/2021. No new central, lobar or segmental of bilateral upper lobe subsegmental pulmonary embolism.2.  Increased metastatic tumor burden as compared to FDG PET/CT of 10/21/2021, as evidenced by increased size of multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules/masses and new lytic metastases.ATTESTATION: I, Francine Jacobson, as teaching physician have reviewed the images, if any, for this patient's exam, and if necessary, have edited the report originally created by Isha Gujrathi.Electronically Signed by: Francine Lee Jacobson, MD, MPH on 11/1/2021  5:17 PM

Report_Text: INDICATION: 68-year-old man with history of a locally advanced,cell carcinoma of the oropharynx, status post chemoradiation.TECHNIQUE: Volumetric CT images of the chest were obtained afterintravenous administration of 50 mL Omnipaque 350 and reformattedinto coronal and sagittal planes, including MIP images.COMPARISON: PET/CT dated 11/01/2016.FINDINGS:CTA:Good contrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree.  There isapparent nonocclusive filling defect seen within the segmentalbranch of the left lower lobe (5, 306) within the segmentalbranch of the right lower lobe (5, 322).  Findings most likelyrelated to mixing artifact, less likely nonocclusive embolus.There is no evidence of right-sided heart strain.The ascending and descending thoracic aorta is normal in courseand contour.Mediastinum:Visualized thyroid gland is unremarkable. The origin of the greatvessels is unremarkable. No mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Coronaryartery calcifications. No hilar lymphadenopathy. No axillarylymphadenopathy. No pericardial or pleural effusion. Calcifiedpleural plaques are seen.Lungs:Subtle right upper lobe bronchial thickening and groundglassopacities. No pneumothorax. There are few scattered less than 4mm nodules within the right upper lobe and right middle lobe andleft lower lobe (10, 89), (10, 84) and (10, 60).Upper abdomen: Surgical material again noted at thegastroesophageal junction. Status post splenectomy. Mild softtissue prominence seen adjacent to the tail of the pancreas mayrepresent splenosis. The pancreas is mildly atrophic.Osseous structures are unremarkable. No fractures. No destructivelytic or sclerotic lesions.IMPRESSION:1. Nonocclusive filling defect within the segmental branch of theleft lower lobe and within the right lower lobe as describedabove most likely related to mixing artifact, less likelynonocclusive embolus. There is high clinical concern forpulmonary embolus, repeat study in or VQ scan can be performedfor further evaluation.2. Subtle right upper lobe bronchial thickening and groundglassopacities could represent an infectious process; clinicalcorrelation is recommended.3. Scattered less than 4 mm nodule as described above, bearswatching on follow-up imaging given history of underlyingmalignancy.I, the teaching physician, have reviewed the images and agreewith the report as written.Critical results were communicated and documented using the AlertNotification of Critical Radiology Results (ANCR) system.Electronically Signed by: Urvi P Fulwadhva, MD on 3/17/2017  4:17 PM

Report_Text: SSX:Hypotension,Hypoxia,INDICATION: 76-year-old female with hypotension and hypoxia.TECHNIQUE: CT scanning was performed through the chest from thethoracic inlet to the adrenal glands following intravenousadministration of 50 mL intravenous Isovue-370 with coronal andsagittal reconstructions.COMPARISON: CT chest, November 5, 2012, August 11, 2011. CT chestPE, September 6, 2011. CT abdomen/pelvis, June 7, 2010.FINDINGS:CT ANGIOGRAM: The study is technically adequate with a goodcontrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree. Smoothnonocclusive mural filling defect within the right main pulmonaryartery (series 6, image 27) is similar to CT chest PE fromSeptember 6, 2011.LUNGS: Right paramediastinal scarring and traction bronchiectasisis consistent with prior radiation exposure. There has been rightmiddle and lower lobectomy. Few scattered areas of cavitation inthe left lung are consistent with prior surgically-provenLangerhans cell histiocytosis are similar to CT from November 5,2012 (e.g. series 6, image 29). There is bibasilar atelectasis.MEDIASTINUM: There is a left thyroid nodule measuring 2.7 x 1.6cm, stable since August 11, 2011. Aortic calcifications arepresent. Coronary artery calcifications are present. There is nomediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy. Heart size isnormal. There is no pericardial effusion.PLEURA: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.BONES: There is no suspicious lytic or blastic bony lesion.ABDOMEN: Low attenuation lesion in the right kidney is similar toprior and consistent with a cyst. The visualized portion of theliver and spleen are unremarkable. A 3.0 x 2.5 cm lesion in theleft adrenal gland is stable from June 7, 2010.IMPRESSION:1. Chronic nonocclusive pulmonary embolus within the right mainpulmonary artery.2. Postsurgical changes, status post right middle and lowerlobectomy for large cell undifferentiated carcinoma, with similarradiation fibrosis in the right paramediastinal region.3. Similar residual nodularity in the left lung, pathologicallyproven to be Langerhans cell histiocytosis.4. Left adrenal lesion, stable since June 7, 2010 and likelyadenoma.5. Left thyroid nodule, stable since August 11, 2011.Critical results were communicated and documented using the AlertNotification of Critical Radiology Results (ANCR) system.I, the teaching physician, have reviewed the images and agreewith the report as written.This report was electronically signed by MICHAEL STELLA MD(T)

Report_Text: CT CHEST PULMONARY ANGIOGRAM (ACUTE)Review of the Electronic Medical Record reveals an additional history of: History of COVID, CAD, GIB, OSA, T2DM, ductal hyperplasia of breast, Barrett's?who presents with chest painTECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT pulmonary angiography was performed after administration of intravenous contrast using tailored dose modulation techniques. 3D angiographic postprocessing techniques were acquired in the form of axial maximum intensity projection images (MIPS).COMPARISON: CT ANGIO CHEST WITH AND WITHOUT CONTRAST 2021-Jan-21FINDINGS:Pulmonary Angiogram:Technical quality: There is adequate opacification of the pulmonary arteries.There are filling defects in the bilateral lower lobe subsegmental arteries (for instance 5:364 and 5:349), and left upper lobe anterior segmental artery (5:197).There are no CT findings of right heart strain.Proximal to the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery, the main pulmonary artery is 3.3 cm in diameter.Devices/Tubes/Lines: None.Lungs: Bilateral lower lobe predominant multifocal groundglass opacities and bibasilar interlobular septal thickening. Bronchial wall thickening especially at the lung bases.Pleura: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.Mediastinum: No pericardial effusion. Tiny hiatal hernia. Mild amount of coronary calcifications. Mitral annular calcifications. Ascending thoracic aorta measures up to about 4.3 cm diameter, similar to prior.Lymph Nodes: No enlarged supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes. Similar subcentimeter subcarinal node (6:41).Upper Abdomen: Cholecystectomy. Partially imaged biliary dilatation, likely compensatory. Suggestion of renal cysts.Chest Wall: No chest wall mass.Bones: No suspicious lytic or blastic lesions. Degenerative changes of the visualized spine.IMPRESSION:1.  Bilateral lower lobe subsegmental and left upper lobe anterior segmental pulmonary emboli. No evidence of right heart strain.2.  Lower lobe predominant multifocal groundglass and interstitial opacities, likely sequela of known recent Covid 19 infection.3.  Unchanged mild dilatation of the ascending thoracic aorta and main pulmonary artery.Critical results were communicated and documented using the Alert Notification of Critical Radiology Results (ANCR) system.ATTESTATION: I, Jeffrey Shyu, as teaching physician have reviewed the images, if any, for this patient's exam, and if necessary, have edited the report originally created by Jingshuo Sun.Electronically Signed by: Jeffrey Y Shyu, MD, MPH on 11/20/2021  7:57 PM

Report_Text: SSX:Chest Pain,Lower Extremity Edema,Shortness of Breath,Hypoxia,INDICATION: SSX:Chest Pain,Lower Extremity Edema,Shortness ofBreath,Hypoxia,TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT scanning was performed through thechest following the intravenous administration of 50 mL Omnipaque350 iodinated contrast, with subsequent saline flush.  Coronaland oblique sagittal reformations were performed. 3D angiographicpostprocessing was performed in the form of axial MIP images.COMPARISON: Chest CT of 8/25/2014CT ANGIOGRAM: The study is technically adequate with appropriatecontrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree. Note is made ofattenuation of a pulmonary artery subsegmental branch in theposterior and inferior left lung. The proximal descending aortais dilated at 4.3 cm, unchanged from prior. No additional areasof filling defects or occlusion noted.CHEST: The patient is status post left lower lobectomy andmediastinal dissection. There are new 3 mm peripheral groundglassnodules in both upper lobes which could be inflammatory inetiology. New groundglass opacity within the right lower lobecould represent atelectasis or pneumonia. Similar appearance ofupper lobe predominant centrilobular emphysema. There is amoderate left-sided multiloculated hydropneumothorax. There is asmall to moderate right-sided pleural effusion.. There is nopericardial effusion. There is no significant mediastinal, hilar,or axillary lymphadenopathy. The patient is status post CABG.Median sternotomy wires are in place.LIMITED ABDOMEN: Limited evaluation of the abdomen shows noabnormalities.IMPRESSION:1. Status post left lower lobectomy with moderate left-sidedmultiloculated hydropneumothorax and small to moderateright-sided pleural effusion.2. Attenuation of a subsegmental left pulmonary artery branchadjacent to the lobectomy site could be related to clot in thestump.3. Groundglass opacity in the left lower lobe could representatelectasis or early pneumonia. Please correlate clinically.4. New subcentimeter groundglass nodules in both upper lobescould be inflammatory in etiology. These should be follow-up tocomplete resolution.Critical results were communicated and documented using the AlertNotification of Critical Radiology Results (ANCR) system.I, the teaching physician, have reviewed the images and agreewith the report as written.This report was electronically signed by M.A. DURAN MENDICUTI MD(T)

MRN_Type_x: PMRN, MGH, BWH, FH, SRH, NWH, NSM, MEE
Report_Text: Diagnostic CT chest pulmonary angiogram was performed WITH intravenous contrast,using standard CT pulmonary angiogram protocol including axial maximum intensityprojection images (MIPs)COMPARISON: Chest CT 4/28/2019.FINDINGS:Technical Quality: The exam is technically adequate for the assessment ofpulmonary embolismPulmonary Arteries: Proximal to the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery,the main pulmonary artery is 2.7 cm in diameter.There is extensive pulmonary embolic burden bilaterally. This includes, distalmost portions of the right and left main pulmonary arteries with thrombus alsonoted in the right upper lobe, right interlobar, right middle lobe, and rightlower lobe pulmonary arteries. Right lower lobe segmental branches are alsoaffected. On the left there is involvement of the left upper lobe pulmonaryartery as well as several segmental branches throughout the left lung.On the iodine blood pool images, there is decreased perfusion in the region ofthe right middle lobe.Lines/tubes : NoneLungs and Airways and pleura: The major airways appear patent. There is a lacy,groundglass appearance to the right middle lobe with scattered areas of moreconsolidative opacity. Given the presence of pulmonary emboli, the findings areconcerning for pulmonary infarct involving the right middle lobe. There is somesubsegmental atelectasis involving the right lower lobe. No consolidation isnoted involving the remainder of the lungs. There is a small to moderate-sizedright pleural effusion.. There is no pneumothorax. No pulmonary edema.Heart and mediastinum:  The thyroid gland demonstrates enlarged heterogeneousleft lobe with calcified nodules. The appearance is unchanged from the priorstudy.. No mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy is seen. The left andright atria appear enlarged. The LV/RV ratio approaches 1. There is mild refluxof IV contrast material into the hepatic veins.Soft tissues:  Normal.Abdomen: Status post cholecystectomy. There is a splenic granuloma. Otherwise,limited contrast-enhanced views of the upper abdomen show no abnormality withinthe visualized liver, spleen, pancreas, or kidneys.  The adrenal glandsdemonstrate unchanged bilateral adrenal nodules measuring up to 17 mm similar toprior study..Bones:  The visualized bony thorax demonstrates multilevel degenerative changes.No suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are demonstrated.IMPRESSION:Multiple bilateral filling defects consistent with pulmonary emboli as describedabove. There is increased lacy groundglass opacity with more consolidativeregions of increased attenuation in the right middle lobe concerning for rightmiddle lobe pulmonary infarct.The critical findings in this report were reported to the the patient's careteam in the emergency room, who responded indicating that the communication wasunderstood. Contact was made at the time of interpretation on Fri, Jun 21 2019at 3:30 AM, within __5_ minutes of observation.Electronically Signed by: James Nash Lawrason, MD on 6/21/2019  4:03 AM

Report_Text: CT CHEST PULMONARY ANGIOGRAM (ACUTE)TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT pulmonary angiography was performed after administration of intravenous contrast using tailored dose modulation techniques. 3D angiographic postprocessing techniques were acquired in the form of axial maximum intensity projection images (MIPS).COMPARISON: CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST 2022-Jul-04TECHNICAL QUALITY: There is adequate opacification of the pulmonary arteries.FINDINGS:Pulmonary Angiogram: Filling defect within a subsegmental right lower lobe pulmonary artery (series 2, image 73). The main pulmonary artery measures 2.8 cm in diameter proximal to its bifurcation. There are no CT findings of right heart strain.Devices / Tubes / Lines: None.Lungs: Moderate cystic and cylindrical bronchiectasis within the bilateral lower lobes, lingula, and right middle lobe with multifocal bronchial debris. Patchy airspace opacities and consolidation within the lower lobes, right middle lobe, and lingula.Pleura: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.Heart / Mediastinum: Cardiomegaly. No pericardial effusion. No thyroid nodules. Small sliding-type hiatal hernia.Lymph Nodes: A right lower paratracheal lymph node measures 12 mm short axis, similar to prior.Upper Abdomen: Partially imaged left upper pole renal cyst.Chest Wall / Soft Tissue: No chest wall mass.Bones: Moderate degenerative changes of the lower thoracic spine. The bones are diffusely osteopenic. Moderate degenerative changes of the glenohumeral joints.IMPRESSION:1.  Positive for a small subsegmental right lower lobe pulmonary embolus.2.  Findings are consistent with acute on chronic aspiration pneumonitis within the lung bases.These findings were discussed with Allison Supranowicz, PA by Dr. Michael Hood via phone on 8/11/2023 3:44 PM.ATTESTATION: I, Dr. Shahmir Kamalian as teaching physician, have reviewed the images for this case and if necessary edited the report originally created by Michael Hood.Electronically Signed by: Shahmir C Kamalian, MD on 8/11/2023  3:46 PM

Report_Text: Requisition too long, Click on >> in Centricity to see Percipio ReqRequisition too long, Click on >> in Centricity to see Percipio ReqINDICATION: Tachycardia, status post PICC line removal.TECHNIQUE: CT was performed through the chest after intravenousadministration of 75 cc Ultravist 370 followed by a saline flush.Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed.COMPARISON: 3/28/2012.CT ANGIOGRAM: The study is technically adequate with a goodcontrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree. There is largepulmonary embolus in the right main pulmonary artery whichextends into the right lower, middle, and upper lobar arteries. Aseparate smaller embolus is present in the anterior and superiorsegment arteries of the left upper lobe. There is slightflattening of the interventricular septum. The LV:RV ratio is1:1. Note is made of a prosthetic mitral valve.CHEST: Atelectasis is present the lung bases, slightly greater onthe left. The lungs appear otherwise clear. There is no pleuralor pericardial effusion.  There is no mediastinal, hilar, oraxillary lymphadenopathy. There is a 7 mm hypodense lesion in theright lobe of thyroid.LIMITED ABDOMEN/PELVIS: Limited coverage of the upper abdomendemonstrates no abnormality in the visualized portions of theliver and spleen. Note is made of a 1.8 cm left adrenal adenoma.BONE: There are no suspicious bone lesions. Sternal wires appearintact. Old healed rib fractures are noted on the right.IMPRESSION:1. Bilateral pulmonary emboli, affecting the right main and twoleft upper lobe segmental arteries. There is no definite evidenceof right heart strain. Echocardiogram may provide furtherinformation in this regard.2. Subcentimeter thyroid hypodense lesion.3. Left adrenal adenoma.Dr. Hargreaves discussed these findings with Dr. Cole at 8:30 PMon 4/13/2012.I, the teaching physician, have reviewed the images and agreewith the report as written.This report was electronically signed by TATIANA ROCHA MD(T)
